metadata.title: AI For the Rest Of Us: Part 1. Explaining how AI works for non-coders… | by Nishul Saperia | Medium
metadata.h1: AI For the Rest Of Us: Part 1
metadata.description: There is huge amounts of hype swirling around today about AI. There is also a huge amount of discussion about it’s impact on society today and in the future. Yet — I’ve seen very little material…

all_paragraphs: There is huge amounts of hype swirling around today about AI. There is also a huge amount of discussion about it’s impact on society today and in the future.
Yet — I’ve seen very little material explaining well how an AI actually works. How is an AI built? What does it actually do inside the black box?
Albert Einstein said once that “If you can’t explain it simply, you don’t understand it well enough.” I rarely see explanations about AI that are simple. So I am going to try.

I’ve called this blog ‘AI for the Rest of Us’ — for those who are not currently participating in the AI revolution and want to understand what is going on. I suspect there are many people who fit into this category.

I know before I started learning about it I felt a little like there was this revolution going on which had no place for me to be part of — or even understand. I want to fix this for everyone else who feels like that.

This is the first of a series of blog posts. To start, I will work through an example of the simplest type of machine learning — linear regression. Many knowledgable people would argue it’s not really even machine learning — it’s more a statistical technique that has been around for ages. And they are right.
Understanding linear regression though will provide a great basis for understanding the more advanced techniques that truly have driven the AI revolution over the past few years.
The use of the term Artificial Intelligence implies that what is being built is intelligent. It’s not. It has no initiative beyond working towards whatever aims you have set it. It has no awareness.
Before I start, a very quick note. The use of the term Artificial Intelligence implies that what is being built is intelligent. It’s not. Not the way we are.

If you teach a machine to do something today, it can only do that. It hasn’t learnt how to do anything else and without you teaching it to do something else, it will never learn it. (It might learn other things faster though on the next thing you teach it if it is a similar task — known as ‘transfer learning’).

It has no initiative beyond working towards whatever aims you have set it. It has no awareness. It doesn’t ‘think’. It simply has learned a way to answer a question which is not easy for a human to figure out themselves easily. This is known as ‘narrow’ AI. ‘General’ AI may be coming (where the machine is self-aware and can learn without a human training it — and much more) but it’s not here yet, and even then the building blocks are most likely to come from ‘narrow’ AI.
Linear Regression comes from a segment of machine learning called ‘supervised learning’.
You would use ‘supervised learning’ when you have some data, and you want this data to give you insights about a question you need to answer.
Additionally, to train the machine in the first place, you have plenty of examples of where you have the data, and you have the answers for that data for your question (this is the ‘training data’).
For this, you would need past data on shopper characteristics (eg age, sex etc) and info on whether they bought or not to feed into the algorithm.
For this you would need previous scans of lungs and answers as to whether the person had lung disease.
Again, you would have examples of houses with all this info provided — and the price it was worth (ideally what it sold at)
You would need previous examples of speech fragments (ideally from a range of different people with possibly different accents!) and the transcription of what they said).
So — how does it work?
This is how you ‘train’ an AI. It’s pretty simple actually right?

Note that to make this work, you need a meaningful amount of examples as training data to train the machine. In fact, getting the right data, and making sure you use it correctly is one of the biggest challenges to building a high-performing machine learning algorithm.
Of course, there is more complicated maths etc that goes into all this, but I will give you a simple example below of linear regression so you can get understand how this works.

When do we want to use linear regression? It’s when the answer to your question is a number. eg share price, house price etc. You wouldn’t use it when trying to predict whether someone has lung cancer — the answer to that is yes/no. The branch of machine learning for that isn’t vastly different but it is a different technique which I will work through in subsequent posts.

Linear Regression is used when the relationship between the data you have, and the answers of your questions are not very clear and easy to figure out. For example — everyone can add two numbers. It’s easy. Furthermore, it’s also easy to program a relationship like this:

Even if the formula looks complicated to you — you can probably figure out the answer with a calculator. Furthermore, you could add a 100 more variables — and you could still calculate the answer (most likely you would write a program to do so or use a spreadsheet) if you knew the relationship between the answer and the inputs.
The key here is that you have a well-defined relationship here between the answer you seek — the house value — and the inputs. You can just do the maths.

The problem is — in the real world — house price value doesn’t always follow a strict formula. It’s not clear and consistent how a house will be valued. Often it will vary for reasons that are hard to figure out. Even if you input every single thing you could possibly know about a house — it might still vary from the best guess.

Furthermore, if you have identified 40 different variables which can affect the house price, it’s very hard for a human to discern and figure out how all those factors affect the price. Things like what is happening in the national economy, the local economy, performance of local schools, changes in local demographics, age of the house, state of decor of the house, sizes of actual rooms, layout of rooms etc etc could all affect the price — and many of the variables themselves will affect how other variables impact the price.

For example, in one zipcode people might really value extra garden space. In others, they value more how close the nearest restaurants are. How the local economy is doing might impact how much people value the size of the rooms so how the price varies with respect to the room sizes will change as the local economy changes! How much each factor affects the price itself will vary depending on other factors.
Ultimately it can get pretty hard to identify the relationship between all these inputs and the house price.
This is where machine learning comes in.

Machine learning can be eloquently described in one line — it’s an advanced pattern recognition algorithm. With enough data, it can identify the relationship between tens, hundreds or even thousands of variables and the outcome — although rarely is it right all of the time.
